reviewText:
A charming game that expresses the innocent sense of curiosity and imagination of a young child in a way I have rarely seen.

If you're not familiar with the Scribblenauts series, they are platformer sandbox puzzle games where you can summon just about any object from the dictionary (with some reasonable exceptions such as copyrighted things, alcohol, and proper nouns) and expect them to interact in a believable way. If you can think of any food, animal, household item, weapon, mythological creature, or vehicle, chances are you can make it appear. We're talking tens of thousands of possibilities. A few surprises can also be summoned, such as a variety of internet memes and special objects, if you can think of them.

You can summon objects, or add adjectives to existing objects, to solve puzzles and make all the townspeople happy. Or, you could just screw around for hours summoning gods and beasts and riding them across the world as your epic mounts, or watching them run loose and terrorize the villagers.

The puzzles are all ridiculously easy, but difficulty is obviously not the point. Personally, my favorite way to play this game is to think of the most obnoxiously ridiculous solutions to every puzzle. Most puzzles will have a bluntly obvious solution, but you can make hilarity ensue if you can think of something creative. For instance, a guy wanted something to help carve his ice sculpture. I gave him a toenail clipper. Hansel and Gretel needed something to make a trail with through the forest. I gave them thumbtacks. A buzzard wanted something to eat. I gave it a dead baby. A tracking dog needed something that smelled like Santa so he could search for Santa. I summoned Santa.

It's an excellent game packed with great humor and content, and it's miles ahead of the Nintendo DS games it was based on. My only complaint is that it got a bit boring after the first few hours, but I fixed that just by taking some breaks and not playing it all on one sitting. But I never once stopped appreciating how wonderful the game is. Highly recommended for anyone who wants to rediscover their inner child, complete with borderline politically incorrect humor, in a way that very few games can provide.

(Achievement hunters: getting 100% is very tedious, as you will need to solve over a hundred riddles to acquire the remaining bonus pieces. Usually you will solve some of them on accident throughout normal gameplay if you try to use creative solutions. However, if you ever get bored, you can just look at a FAQ to fully complete the game effortlessly.)

Scribblenauts Unlimited is one of my favorite games in the Scribblenauts series.
However... this is entirely because of the object creator and character creator.

While I AM recommending this game, I feel the need to list a couple major issues I had with it:
-The puzzles are much easier and less interesting/creative than the ones in Super Scribblenauts

-They got rid of destructable terrain entirely (you can no longer dig/destroy the land like you could in Super Scribblenauts)

-The maps are very crowded and there's no sandbox mode like there was in Super Scribblenauts

As you may have noticed, these are all downgrades from the previous Scribblenauts game (Super Scribblenauts), and while these issues do make the game a lot less fun, the new features mostly make up for it.
I rate this game a 7.5/10 and recommend getting Super Scribblenauts if you have any of the devices it's available for.

June 22, 2015
Scribblenauts Unlimited is a strange game, functioning best as a sandbox to play with creativity and absurdity. Focusing on completing the game tasks can become boring, and a fair amount of objectives feel like padding. Completionists will be annoyed by the amount of chores needed to 100% the game.

This may sound like the game is bad, and that could be argued. Approached as a series of tasks to save Lily, the game can feel a bit slow. However, sometimes you need to forget the quests and just mess around. Arm shotguns with shotguns, then hand them to a musical afro. Build a tower of dirty jesters, riding a hated jester on the bottom. Give a dog-fearing man a dog whistle and watch him panic. Play around, and you can really see the pure fun of this game. I've spent at least an hour catching my breath after hilarious events, most of which I didn't expect or plan. That alone is worth the time and money, in this era of pretentious art games and multiplayer communities that make you hate humanity.

Do you want to laugh, preferably without vulgarity? Can you come up with some silly ideas to see what happens? I'd recommend Scribblenauts Unlimited.  I don't have much idea about the Unmasked version, doesn't seem to change much beyond the missions, and I figure the Unlimited Workshop community is stronger. I got the game from a Humble Bundle key  <3 Fred but I would recommend the game easily at 25% off for $15 USD.

reviewText:
Imagine being able to create whatever you wanted just by writing it in a book. Now, instead of using this book to give yourself a flying rainbow llama, you use it to help people in need. This is Scribblenauts Unlimited, the third game in the Scribblenauts series.

You play as Maxwell, a young boy who has been given the gift of a magic notebook from his parents. Maxwell then uses the notebook to give a rotten apple to a hungry man, and angers him. The man puts a curse on Lily, his sister, who now slowly turns to stone. To stop this, Maxwell has to make up for his trickery by collecting Starites from people, to free his sister from the curse.

The gameplay in Scribblenauts Unlimited is basic, but it is obtained and used well. I was never confused by the controls or wandered around pressing buttons. The notebook feature is easy to use, and writing something with multiple meanings (say, 'bat') will bring up a menu to select which type of object you would like. There is also a backpack feature that allows you to save your favourite creations for easier access later, but I rarely used this feature as I created new and different things all of the time.

While Scribblenauts Unlimited is simple, its charming art style is colourful, playful and different to a lot of other games that I am used to. Playing the first two games on the Nintendo DS, Scribblenauts Unlimited combines the series-defining mechanics of the first game with the creativity and art style of Super Scribblenauts, building a game that is definitely one of the best puzzle games available on PC. While this game is definitely directed towards a younger audience, I couldn't help but pick up the third instalment of this amazing franchise.

There are no borders in Scribblenauts Unlimited. Unlike the first two games, Scribblenauts Unlimited is set it over 20 different locations, which when unlocked are accessible all the time, creating an open world to explore and invent wonderful contraptions and experiments. Never in any other game have I seen so much creative freedom.

To conclude, Scribblenauts Unlimited is a flawless addition to the series, and definitely a game that will consume a fair amount of play time.

9.8/10

reviewText:
Scribblenauts Unlimited is an adventure puzzle game. As Maxwell, save your sister Lily from a curse by creating happiness around the world with the use of your magical notepad that can create anything you can write.

Pros: The game has an astonishing amount of potential content. Almost any word and adjective you can think of, you can create by typing it. There is a lot of different method to resolve any situation, and the fun comes in finding new and unexpected ways to do so. You will find yourself attempting different solutions again and again even after you already succeeded just to see if you can find an easter egg or game secret. Usable created objects also add game elements to work with, and combining people or objects with one or more adjectives increases the possibilities tenfold.

Cons: The game is short, you can breeze through it, getting the Starites you need to win the game within a few hours. Many of the puzzles are easy, half of which can usually be resolved with the same few objects. There are multiple passageways to move around a level, but they are often useless as it won't take time for you to always make sure you have a jet-pack or pair of wings to move around. Unless you want to explore the possibilities, you won't find much replayability as resolving a puzzle in different ways still ends up with the exact same result.

Verdict: â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜† - Next on your list!

If you're looking for an exciting story, grand adventure or mind-bending puzzles, turn away. But if you're looking for an entertaining time trying to push the limit of the game, and exploring just how far you can go, it's a great one. The Steam Workshop makes it easier than ever to add dozens, if not hundreds of new objects and options, assuming you don't use the object creator to add your own. Furthermore, the game is great for all ages, maybe even more so for younger gamers. Of course, if you didn't like previous Scribblenauts games, you're unlikely to enjoy this one. But if you did, Scribblenauts Unlimited will go where previous ones never went before!

5th Cell have made a few very good games that I have played, and this is one of them. This game company has made a few games that can really inspire creativity, such as Drawn To Life and Scribblenauts, though of course inspire creativity  in different ways.

Scribblenauts is a game that encourages you to come up with ways to solve moderatly easy puzzles, where there is no one solution. Because there is no one solution, it has high replay value, with you figuring out what else works, and different ways to do the same thing. At first you might start out summoning a sponge to clean a wall, later you will be using aardvarks for everything.

This game has changed a lot since it's start on the Nintendo DS, and you can even MAKE new things with parts of things from the game, and even script their behaviour! Or if you are no good at making things, you can download some from the Steam Workshop!

There are very few flaws in this game, as no game is perfect. One flaw I find is not really a flaw, but can be seen as one, you have way too much freedom in this game. Limits really work well in certain games, and with games with too much freedom you can get bored, or you see no challenge. reviewText:
This is one of my favorite games of all time.  I often play it whenever I need cheering up.

It has lackluster reviews, and I've noticed almost everyone that rates it mediocre or bad plays it differently than I do.  You could consider this both a review and a guide to having fun with the game.  Don't worry, there won't be spoilers.

If you're out of elementary school, and play the game in the most straightforward way, it will be too easy.  It amounts to a graphical adventure where you can access almost every item in the game by typing the name, letting you bypass anything resembling a puzzle.  While this might be viewed as a problem by teenagers and adults playing the game, it's actually a good thing for children, who can use it as a fun way to exercise their vocabulary skills.

Teenagers and adults playing the game should use their creativity.  The game is usually surprisingly flexible in how you can achieve a goal.  The only restrictions it normally has are: you can't use real people's names, or anything involving drugs, prejudice, or sex, and you often can't kill anybody.

Suggestions to get you started:
Be indirect.  Creating things people ask for and sticking adjectives on the problem is boring.  Create other beings and complex Rube Goldberg contraptions made of multiple objects to solve problems.  Watch the chaos as unexpected interactions ensue!  When your solutions cause more problems, add more elements to try to fix those, rather than changing or removing anything.
Be lazy.  See how little you can create while still solving a problem indirectly.  This usually involves heavy use of side effects.  You may be able to solve multiple problems on the same level with one action.
Be impractical.  Pick a role and stubbornly stick to it.  The best roles are those least suited to a hero (e.g. cook, janitor, tailorâ€¦).  Dress the part and give yourself appropriate adjectives.  Try to solve all problems using only things that are in theme.  MacGyver would be proud.
Do no harm.  When dealing with a problematic creature or object, try to create and use some other creatures or objects that harmlessly neutralize it, rather than fighting or destroying it.
Provide unhelpful help.  Be an evil genie.  Do what someone asked you to do, but make sure it has side effects they won't like, or doesn't achieve their goal.
Consider what would happen ifâ€¦  For example, what would happen if a prince, turned into a frog, was given a werewolf princess to kiss?
Played this way it should have you laughing your head off.  You may lose the level (usually due to an accidental death), but have so much fun you won't care.

The game does have some flaws.

It doesn't recognize every correctly spelled word.  That would have been impossible to program and create art for.

Some goals are too restrictive to allow creativity.  Sometimes there is only one solution.  There should be at least three significantly different solutions.  Better playtesting could have caught this.

There are â€œfetch questsâ€.  They involve going to some part of the map, which is usually unobstructed, picking up a item, and carrying it back to the person that asked for it.  You can't use your magical notebook to do this, and it's unhumorous, uncreative, and unchallenging.  Hopefully the authors will stop including these in the future.

While I love what the object editor can do, I hate how it does it.  The primary pain-point is how difficult it is to â€œdrawâ€ a new object.  You have to do it by lumping together existing art assets.  The second worst pain-point is how difficult it is to get the behavior you want.  You can only create new behaviors by tuning settings on existing ones.  While you can argue this is â€œcreative problem solvingâ€, it fits poorly with the design of the rest of the game.  Making a item in game is as easy as typing the name.  Making items in the object editor should be similarly painless.  We'd be better off with a design that imports SVG and allows scripting in some common, efficient, sandboxable, programming language, like JavaScript or Lua.

There is no way to create new levels at all.  This could have greatly extended interest in the game.

Overall, I think this is one of the finest games ever made, and look forward to more in the series.

*Overall:
I would recommend this game to anyone who:
>Enjoys puzzle games

>Likes casual, simple games

To be fair there isnt really anything about this game i would say is a deterrent as levels are creative and incorporate a smooth playability, everything works perfectly in tow and it gives you a good laugh here and there so that definitley helps, the only thing i could say is that i wish i could spawn more items and interesting objects that i would like to have been able to use and more playability, maybe a create my own level generator or even some sort of online playability though im not sure as to how much you could get from online, alas.

In any case in general i would say this game is pretty fun, especially for the younger generation and can be a bit educational as it can teach you proper spelling and more thinking outside the box, i give it an 8.5/10.

reviewText:
Scribblenauts Unlimited is a VERY fun installation in the Scribblenauts series.  New to the game is the object editor, a very easy to use and creative way of making your own interactive objects.  You can change sizes, colors, and shapes, but the one thing that made me upset was that you can't DRAW your own objects.  This limits you to using only pre-made things in the game, forcing you to combine them if you want something unique.

Also new to Scribblenauts is its vast world.  From the city, to a desert, and even to space, you can take Maxwell (or one of his many brothers) on missions around the virtual globe.  Each level has challenges awaiting you that can be very simple or complex.  On the other hand, many missions have simple solutions.  For example, if a boy is unhappy, you can make a clown, video game, etc.  The possibilities are endless, but the entertainment level with some obstacles is limited.

All in all, I still like playing the game.  Even after you finish all the side-missions and campaign, you can still make your own objects and re-create your favorite characters and scenes from movies, video games, and books.  I highly recommend this game for anyone who wants to share their ideas with others and explore Maxwell's world.

reviewText:
The basic gameplay of Scribblenauts is solving little puzzles by creating objects that you can then use to manipulate the world. Most of the puzzles are very straightforward, and allow the player to come up with many different solutions, but every now and then I would get stuck on something. Usually it was because the answer the game was looking for was something completely different than I was thinking, so it was unable to interpret how the objects I created were supposed to be a solution. reviewText:
Scribblenauts Unlimited is a title in its own genre: to the general public there is no game quite like it (and to this day I have not found any alternatives myself either). While the gameplay should be known to most of my readers, for the sake of completion I will elaborate on the game's objectives and means to succeed in them.

The protagonist is Maxwell, a kid that gets his hands on a notebook with a magical power, being that everything written down in the notebook will magically appear. As â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ and malicious little children are, he seized the opportunity to make the lives of others miserable, that is until a magician curses his sister and she is slowly consumed and converted into rock. The only way to stop this from happening is for him to make people, as well as animals and sometimes even inanimate objects, happy again. The player is presented with a sidescrolling 2D level including Maxwell, the aforementioned entities, and loads of hints that should indicate the player what to spawn for those in need. Some of these entities initiate a small storyline, while others are as simple as spawning a glass of water for someone that claims to be thirsty.

There has obviously been a lot of work put into the levels as to not make them linear, and while this succeeded, the overall premise of the game makes it that it will still appear linear to the player. After all, your mission is to spawn the things you're asked for. The sandbox aspect of the game has some potential as far as humor is concerned (have you ever worn a pants that's armed with a sword and is fighting your t-shirt?), but to some this will be entertaining for a shorter period of time than it is to others. The music and sound complements the visuals and while these aspects aren't exactly extraordinary, they are good enough.

In general I'd spend â‚¬10,- to â‚¬15,- if I was less cynical of a person. The reason I wouldn't scoop out that small amount from my budget is that I easily got bored with the sandbox aspect, but you'll have to keep in mind that I'm one of few uncommon gamers that is unable to enjoy the sandbox aspect of many other games like GTA1/4, Saints Row III and Just Cause 2, so I'm sure this will still appeal to a lot of folks out there.

reviewText: Scribblenauts Unlimited is a brilliant concept. You're faced with a myriad of problems throughout the game and have to solve them by conjuring items from a magic notebook. The number of items you can conjure is impressive. Everything from the Kraken, to God, to microbes and dark matter can be summoned to solve challenges. You can spend ages figuring out the most ingenious way to solve a puzzle, and seeing your solution finally work is satisfying. Unfortunately, there's little incentive to solve puzzles this way when more obvious methods are just as effective. Some items cannot be summoned at all, even if they seem obvious (blood comes to mind). Nevertheless, Scribblenauts is a charming puzzler which can be fun for adults as well as the kids.

reviewText: When the original Scribblenauts came out for the DS, it was one of my favorite games. While it did not have the option to customize objects or use adjectives, most levels were both fun and challenging, forcing you to push your creativity's limits in order to reach the starite. Scribblenauts Unlimited allows much more depth with creating items, but the levels/puzzles do not reach beyond simply creating a category of object when prompted. There are no action levels in Scribblenauts Unlimited and as a result none of the levels are really challenging and there is no satisfaction in completing them. The object editor also allows you to create overpowered objects as well, decreasing what little challenge there is. It is fun to fool around with the object editor, but Scribblenauts Unlimited does not offer much depth beyond customizing your own objects.

reviewText: This is a really chill puzzle game where you generate objects, creatures, etc. from an impressively large parser (including adjectives) to solve tasks in each of the game's areas. If you're someone who just wants to beat a game, you can do it in an evening or two, but people who like sandboxes or games that give you the ability to just goof off and use your imagination will probably get the most out of this game.

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

If you have played Scribblenauts on NDS or IOS and are hoping this game is exactally the same you are sadly wrong. This game is fun but when it comes to creating things out of words it cant be compared to the NDS or IOS port. Simply because it doesnt recognize half the words you put together. For example in the first city there is gaffiti drawn on the wall and you have to get rid of it, So you may be thinking lets get creative with the words so you type Paint Eraser, or Paint Thinner and the game asks you did you mean this, and it gives you 5 pages of words you possibly dont know to replace the words you typed. Its like they took the worst part of gooogle search from the year 2005 by saying did you mean this, and made it into a game.

The game is really fun once you get past the flaw of being creative with words and you can even make your own creations and replace other creations with your own in a level such as a ant with your own design by clicking on it and recreating it. But with the 1 flaw thats holding it back it feels like its not the same scribblenauts from the NDS or IOS and was simply made poorly as if the game was made by a different company.

The game is a defininate buy but if your a fan of the Original games on NDS or IOS then prepare for extreme ammounts of being angry because the game wont let you make paint thinner for paint but somehow an eraser can get rid of the paint which has no creativity at all when you are trying to get crazy creative with word creations.
